newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: SOCCER-BELL GETS WORLD CUP BACK PAY SEVEN YEARS LATE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BELL GETS WORLD CUP BACK PAY SEVEN YEARS LATE.

text.p: Former Cameroon goalkeeper Joseph-Antoine Bell will finally be paid for taking part in the World Cup finals in Italy -- seven years after the event.

Bell sought the help of FIFA in his battle for payment of 37,000 French francs ($6,430) and a spokesman for the game's governing body said on Tuesday the Cameroon Football Federation had finally agreed to pay.
"He (Bell) asked FIFA for support and based on the documents we received he was entitled to it," FIFA spokesman Andreas Herren said. "The Cameroonian federation said they would comply and pay him."
Bell is the only member of the 1990 squad to have persisted with trying to get his money.
The former France-based goalkeeper, who played for Marseille and St Etienne, was a controversial figure at the World Cup finals in Italy in 1990 where Cameroon reached the quarter-finals.
Bell sat on the bench throughout the tournament after being dropped on the eve of the opening game against Argentina in Milan because of a dispute with team officials over payment.
He was also dropped after two games at the last World Cup finals in the U.S. after leading a threatened strike by the Cameroonian team.
"If a player is entitled to money then he should get it," said Herren. "For FIFA it was important the principle was upheld not the amount."
Bell, who retired at the age of 40 two years ago, recently lost his bid to win election for president of the Cameroonian Football Federation.
Reports from the Cameroon say other members of the 1990 squad are now also expected to claim back pay from the federation.
